content.value_statement: Converting free users to paid requires strategic upgrade moments. This skill helps design effective in-app paywalls, upgrade flows, and upsell modals that respect user experience while maximizing conversion rates.
actual_capabilities: Design feature lock paywalls that explain value before asking for upgrade
Create usage limit prompts that motivate without frustrating users
Build trial expiration screens that summarize value received
Develop soft upgrade prompts for non-blocking suggestions
Optimize timing and frequency of upgrade prompts
Design team and seat upgrade flows for B2B contexts
limitations: Does not implement payment processing or checkout systems
Does not access user analytics data or A/B test results
Does not integrate with specific billing providers
Provides design guidance only, not code implementation

prompt_templates.title: Basic paywall design
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a paywall for our [product type] that appears when users try to access [paid feature]. Our target audience is [description]. What should the headline, value demonstration, and CTA say?
prompt_templates.scenario: Designing a feature gate for a specific paid capability

prompt_templates.title: Trial expiration flow
prompt_templates.prompt: Our [X]-day trial ends in [Y] days. Users have accessed [feature 1] and [feature 2]. Design an expiration screen that summarizes their value and encourages upgrade.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating trial expiration messaging for engaged users

prompt_templates.title: Usage limit upgrade prompt
prompt_templates.prompt: Users on our free plan hit their limit of [X] projects. Design a paywall that shows their progress and motivates upgrade to Pro for unlimited access.

prompt_templates.title: A/B test variations
prompt_templates.prompt: We want to test [X] different paywall approaches. Design 3 variations with different headlines, value presentations, and CTAs for our A/B test.
prompt_templates.scenario: Preparing multiple paywall variants for experimentation

best_practices: Show paywalls after users experience the aha moment, not before they understand the product value.
Provide clear escape hatches so users can continue with free features without feeling trapped.
Personalize paywall copy based on which features the user has already tried.
anti_patterns: Hiding the close button or making it difficult to dismiss the paywall.
Asking for upgrade before users have experienced meaningful value.
Using misleading urgency or guilt-trip tactics that erode trust.

faq.question: When should I show a paywall?
faq.answer: Show paywalls after users experience value, such as after completing key actions, hitting usage limits, or using premium features. Avoid showing during onboarding before they understand the product.

faq.question: What is the difference between a hard gate and soft prompt?
faq.answer: A hard gate blocks access to a feature until upgrade. A soft prompt shows upgrade value while allowing the user to continue. Use soft prompts for encouragement and hard gates only for core paid features.

faq.question: How often should I show upgrade prompts?
faq.answer: Limit prompts to 2-3 per session with a cool-down period after dismissal. Track user signals like rage clicks to avoid showing prompts to annoyed users.

faq.question: What makes an effective paywall headline?
faq.answer: Focus on the benefit users will receive, not the price. Use action-oriented language like Unlock, Get, or Start. Personalize when possible with user names or usage data.

faq.question: Should I show pricing on the paywall?
faq.answer: Display pricing clearly but focus on value first. Annual discounts can be highlighted as savings. Some products de-emphasize price until the upgrade CTA for higher conversion.

faq.question: How do I handle users who dismiss the paywall?
faq.answer: Respect their decision with a friendly message. Set a cool-down period before showing another prompt. Consider offering a smaller commitment like an annual discount for hesitant users.
